Scott Stirling wrote:

>  > -----Original Message-----
> > From: Eric Armstrong [mailto:eric.armstrong@...]
> > Scott Stirling wrote:
> > > What would it be like
> > > to idiomaticize Testability as a marker interface in Java?
> > >
> > > One idea is that "implements Testable" could mean that a runtime
> flag
> > > could be used to enable/disable a set of test methods (a la
> JUnit's
> > > test**** method naming pattern) in classes.  Just a thought.
> >
> > Heck of a thought.
> >
> > I would expect:
> >    a) The class structure would contain the test methods, but they
> >        wouldn't be loaded in the absence of a -test flag, or some
> such.
> >
> >    b) With the -test option present, a framework would exist to help
> you
> >
> >         experiment with the APIs, uncovering gaps in the
> documentation.
> >         (If I give an empty string as an argument, do I get a null
> > String, an empty string, or an exception?)
>
> Yes, both of these would be cool, especially if a reporting mechanism
> and
> driver was built-into the JVM.  Not likely, but it's not impossible.
>
> >    c) API documentation would have a link to a page containing test
> >        methods that would exist only if the class was testable.
> >
> > Such a thing could be really cool, self-documenting addition to
> > libraries.
>
> That is a pretty cool idea.
>
> > What the heck *is* unit testing, anyway? If it is "class methods",
> then
> > JUnitDoclet made sense. But if it is "basic operations", isn't that
> more
> > like integration testing? Or is there a middle ground, say, as
> package-
> > level operations?
> >
> > Right now, I'm seeing "unit" as one or more of:
> >   * method
> >   * class
> >   * package
> >   * use case
> >
> > Are there any other candidates? Are any of these automatically
> > ruled out? What exactly does the word "unit" mean, in this
> > context?
>
> I go by the Robert Binder definition, which is couched in a
> comprehensive
> thesis about the importance of identifying appropriate testing
> techniques
> and bug predictions for components at different scopes.  But the
> scopes used
> are traditional categories (in QA engineering, Boris Beizer and
> Gelnford
> Meyers pretty well represent the founders of tradition).
>
> From Binder's "Testing Object-Oriented Systems," p. 45:
>
> "The scope of a test is the collection of software components to be
> verified. [...] Scope is traditionally designated as unit, integration
> or
> system."
>
> "The scope of a unit test typically comprises a relatively small
> executable.
> In object-oriented programming, an object of a class is the smallest
> executable unit, but test messages must be sent to a method, so we can
> speak
> of method scope testing.  A test unit may consist of a class, several
> related classes (a cluster), or an executable binary file.  Typically
> it is
> a cluster of interdependent classes."
>
> And, some gems from the chapter on "Classes" (chapter 10), p. 351:
>
> Q: Why Test at Class Scope?
> A [edited for length]:
> - System-level testing cannot exercise components to the same degree
> as
> class scope testing.
> - Trying to exercise a class through its clients is usually like
> trying to
> pick up a dime with boxing gloves. [one of my favorite lines from
> Binder's
> book]
> - The longer the time between creation of a bug and its debut as a
> failure,
> the higher the cost of correction.
> - Effective class scope testing reduces schedule risk and improves
> productivity.
> - It is poor practice, at best, to foist testing on to developers of
> client
> classes.
>
> Scott Stirling
> Framingham, MA
